messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Enumeration and Unimodular Equivalence of Empty Delta-Modular Simplices The article was prepared under financial support of Russian Science Foundation grant No 21-11-00194.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Consider a class of simplices defined by systems A‚Äãx‚â§bùê¥ùë•ùëèAx\leq b of linear inequalities with ŒîŒî\Delta-modular matrices. A matrix is called ŒîŒî\Delta-modular, if all its rank-order sub-determinants are bounded by ŒîŒî\Delta in an absolute value. In our work we call a simplex ŒîŒî\Delta-modular, if it can be defined by a system A‚Äãx‚â§bùê¥ùë•ùëèAx\leq b with a ŒîŒî\Delta-modular matrix Aùê¥A. And we call a simplex empty, if it contains no points with integer coordinates. In literature, a simplex is called lattice-simplex, if all its vertices have integer coordinates. And a lattice-simplex called empty, if it contains no points with integer coordinates excluding its vertices. Recently, assuming that ŒîŒî\Delta is fixed, it was shown in [37] that the number of ŒîŒî\Delta-modular empty simplices modulo the unimodular equivalence relation is bounded by a polynomial on dimension. We show that the analogous fact holds for the class of ŒîŒî\Delta-modular empty lattice-simplices. As the main result, assuming again that the value of the parameter ŒîŒî\Delta is fixed, we show that all unimodular equivalence classes of simplices of the both types can be enumerated by a polynomial-time algorithm. As the secondary result, we show the existence of a polynomial-time algorithm for the problem to check the unimodular equivalence relation for a given pair of ŒîŒî\Delta-modular, not necessarily empty, simplices.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The b-hull of an integer program",
        "Integer programming, lattices, and results in fixed dimension",
        "Inequalities from two rows of a simplex tableau",
        "On lov√°sz‚Äôlattice reduction and the nearest lattice point problem",
        "Duality for mixed-integer convex minimization",
        "Intersection cuts‚Äîa new type of cutting planes for integer programming",
        "New bounds in some transference theorems in the geometry of numbers",
        "Inequalities for convex bodies and polar reciprocal lattices in rnsuperscriptùëüùëõr^{n}",
        "The flatness theorem for nonsymmetric convex bodies via the local theory of banach spaces",
        "Integer Points in Polyhedra",
        "An algorithmic theory of lattice points in polyhedra",
        "A polynomial time algorithm for counting integral points in polyhedra when the dimension is fixed",
        "Short rational generating functions for lattice point problems",
        "Optimality certificates for convex minimization and helly numbers",
        "A geometric approach to cut-generating functions",
        "Computing the continuous discretely",
        "Constructive characterizations of the value-function of a mixed-integer program i",
        "Constructive characterizations of the value function of a mixed-integer program ii",
        "Quotient singularities, integer ratios of factorials, and the riemann hypothesis",
        "Minimal valid inequalities for integer constraints",
        "Proximity and flatness bounds for linear integer optimization",
        "On the complexity of quasiconvex integer minimization problem",
        "Hollow polytopes of large width",
        "Integer programming, lattice algorithms, and deterministic volume estimation",
        "Enumerative lattice algorithms in any norm via m-ellipsoid coverings",
        "Algebraic And geometric ideas in the theory of discrete optimization",
        "Relaxations of mixed integer sets from lattice-free polyhedra",
        "Empty simplices of large width",
        "On barvinok‚Äôs algorithm for counting lattice points in fixed dimension",
        "Fast integer programming in fixed dimension",
        "Integer conic function minimization based on the comparison oracle",
        "Faster algorithms for sparse ilp and hypergraph multi-packing/multi-cover problems",
        "The width and integer optimization on simplices with bounded minors of the constraint matrices",
        "A faster algorithm for counting the integer points number in Œ¥ùõø\\delta-modular polyhedra",
        "FPT-algorithms for some problems related to integer programming",
        "FPT-algorithm for computing the width of a simplex given by a convex hull",
        "On Œ¥ùõø\\delta-modular integer linear problems in the canonical form and equivalent problems",
        "On integer programming with bounded determinants",
        "On the maximal width of empty lattice simplices",
        "On lattice width of lattice-free polyhedra and height of hilbert bases",
        "The complete classification of empty lattice 4-simplices",
        "Covering minima and lattice-point-free convex bodies",
        "On the width of lattice-free simplices",
        "A quantitative formulation of kronecker‚Äôs theory of approximation",
        "Computing parametric rational generating functions with a primal barvinok algorithm",
        "Korkin-zolotarev bases and successive minima of a lattice and its reciprocal lattice",
        "Linear and integer programming vs linear integration and counting: a duality viewpoint",
        "Integer programming with a fixed number of variables",
        "Lattice-free simplices with lattice width 2‚Äãd‚àío‚Äã(d)2ùëëùëúùëë2d-o(d)",
        "A strong dual for conic mixed-integer programs",
        "On four-dimensional terminal quotient singularities",
        "Terminal quotient singularities in dimensions three and four",
        "Constructing lattice-free gradient polyhedra in dimension two",
        "Distances between non-symmetric convex bodies and the m‚Äãm‚àóùëösuperscriptùëömm^{*}-estimate",
        "Theory of linear and integer programming",
        "An introduction to empty lattice simplices",
        "Asymptotically fast computation of Hermite normal forms of integer matrices",
        "Classification of empty lattice 4-simplices of width larger than 2",
        "The structure of simple sets in ‚Ñ§3superscript‚Ñ§3\\mathbb{Z}^{3}",
        "A polynomial algorithm for minimizing discrete convic functions in fixed dimension",
        "Lattice tetrahedra",
        "Integer programming duality: Price functions and sensitivity analysis"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Enumeration and Unimodular Equivalence of Empty Delta-Modular Simplices The article was prepared under financial support of Russian Science Foundation grant No 21-11-00194., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
